metadata.case_name: Immani Venkanna and sons v. Gollapalli Ramalingamurthi

facts.text: Appellants and respondent 2 are members of an undivided Hindu family.
Respondent 1 purchased the suit properties on April 1, 1936 in a sale by Official Receiver in insolvency of respondent 2. Registered sale deed Ex. P-4 issued on September 21, 1936.
Respondent 1 obtained possession after partitioning with Rayudu, brother of respondent 2.
In October 1938, appellants and respondent 2 trespassed on properties, leading respondent 1 to file suit for declaration of title, possession, and mesne profits.

Respondent 2 sustained heavy business losses, indebted to Rs. 25,000. To protect properties from creditors, executed collusive nominal mortgage deed Ex. P-9 for Rs. 1,000 in favour of respondent 1 on June 16, 1933, on advice of respondent 1's father-in-law.
Similar nominal transfer deed Ex. P-12 executed on August 6, 1933, after release from earlier non-possessory mortgage Ex. P-11 dated July 21, 1930.

Insolvency petition I.P. No. 91 of 1933 filed against respondent 2 on September 15, 1933 by creditor. Respondent 2 adjudicated insolvent; Official Receiver sold properties subject to nominal mortgages.
Kanthamani Seshamma (junior mother-in-law of respondent 2) purchased properties benami in name of respondent 1, with condition to reconvey to family of respondent 2.
Trial court tried preliminary issues 5,8,9: Found jurisdiction, valued suit at Rs. 2,411-7-2. Issue 5: Sale did not bind appellants' shares, following Ramasastrulu v. Balakrishna Rao.
Respondent 1 amended plaint: Properties self-acquired of respondent 2; alternative prayer for whole or 1/5th share.

Trial judge found properties joint family; alternatively blended; appellants' shares not vested in Official Receiver; purchase benami for appellants; no possession by respondent 1; sale fraudulent to defraud creditors, fraud carried out; but parties estopped from pleading fraud. Preliminary decree for 1/5th share in some items, compensation for others, future mesne profits.
Appeal No. 288/1943 by respondent 1, cross-objections by appellants. Appellate court dismissed both.
Second Appeal No. 1656/1947 by respondent 1, cross-objections by appellants. Contentions on Provincial Insolvency Amendment Act No. 25/1948 s.28A retrospective; surprise on issue 1(a) benami.
High Court remanded issue 1(a); trial court found fraud on creditors successful.
High Court (Division Bench) held appellants estopped from pleading fraud, decreed whole properties to respondent 1.
Transaction fraudulent plan by respondent 1 and 2 to defraud creditors; achieved; possession with respondent 2 and appellants.

legal_issues.text: Whether, in a case where transferor and transferee are equal in fraud, fraud contemplated carried out, transferor/appellants can plead fraud in defence against transferee's suit for possession.
Whether Official Receiver's sale bound appellants' shares in joint family property.
Whether properties self-acquired or joint family.
Vires of Provincial Insolvency Amendment Act No. 25 of 1948 inserting s.28A.

petitioner_arguments.text: Transfer benami, no real ownership by respondent 1; antecedent history of collusive documents without consideration to protect from creditors.
Issue 1(a) surprise, no opportunity; fraud not effectively carried out, no estoppel.
Where parties equally guilty, estoppel not applicable; possession rests where it lies (ex dolo malo non oritur actio; in pari delicto potior est conditio possidentis).
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Maxims: ex dolo malo non oritur actio; in pari delicto potior est conditio possidentis
Provincial Insolvency Amendment Act No. 25 of 1948

respondent_arguments.text: Purchased bona fide from Official Receiver; obtained possession; properties self-acquired or alternatively entitled to whole/1/5th.
Appellants/respondent 2 estopped from pleading own fraud (nemo allegans suam turpitudinem audiendus est).
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Maxims: nemo allegans suam turpitudinem audiendus est

respondent_arguments.text: s.28A retrospective, sale binds family shares.

court_reasoning.text: Public policy: Allowing plea of fraud less injurious; Court not instrument of fraud by decreeing for respondent 1; passive to let possession rest where it lies.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Paramount consideration of public interest requires plea of fraud allowed; estate remain where it rests.

court_reasoning.text: Maxims analyzed: ex turpi causa non oritur actio applies over nemo allegans; both parties confederates, transferee seeks active Court aid.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No estoppel where both agreed to fraud.

court_reasoning.text: Consensus of High Courts (except Madras) favors possession where it lies; Madras view incorrect.
s.84 Trusts Act inapplicable; case outside its categories.
Conveyance void ab initio, no title passes.

holdings.text: In mutual fraud successfully carried out, defence can plead fraud; no estoppel; possession rests where it lies.

precedents_cited.relevance: Father/manager's right to sell sons' shares for family binding purposes does not vest in Official Receiver.
Madras view that fraud successful estops pleading benami; overruled implicitly.

precedents_cited.case_name: Guddappa Chikkappa Kurbar v. Balaji Ramji Dange
precedents_cited.relevance: Possession remains where it rests between fraud participants.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sidlingappa Bin Ganeshappa v. Hirwa Bin Tukasa
precedents_cited.relevance: Dissenting view reversed by Full Bench.

precedents_cited.case_name: Preomath Koer v. Kazi Mahomed Shazid
T.P. Petherpermal Chetty v. R. Muntandi Servai
precedents_cited.relevance: Approves Mayne's statement on fraud not carried out vs carried out.

precedents_cited.case_name: Doe Dem. Roberts v. Roberts Widow
precedents_cited.relevance: No man alleges own fraud to avoid deed; criticized.
No Court aid to action from immoral/illegal act.

statutes_cited.name: Provincial Insolvency Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Retrospective effect on vesting of sons' shares; vires not pressed.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Trusts Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Inapplicable as transferee not in possession, fraud carried out, equal guilt.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; High Court judgment set aside; respondent 1's suit dismissed. Plea of fraud upheld; properties remain with appellants and respondent 2 as fraud successful and parties equal.

key_quotes.text: "ex dolo malo non oritur actio" or "ex turpi causa non oritur actio" ... "in pari delicto potior est conditio possidentis".
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core maxims applied favoring possession where it rests.

key_quotes.text: The paramount consideration of public interest requires that the plea of fraud should be allowed to be raised and tried, and if it is upheld the estate should be allowed to remain where it rests.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: No Court will lend its aid to a man who founds his cause of action upon an immoral or an illegal act.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quotes Lord Mansfield; refuses aid to fraudulent plaintiff.
